video.title: The Inpatient and Doom VFR (Zero Punctuation)

captions.text:
So I thought it was about time we had a revisit,
or rather, a verisit, to the world of VR.

PSVR, that is, which stands for Playstation
VR and not, as one might expect, Pukey Sickness
Vomit Receptacle.

I&#39;m told the motion sickness thing is just
a matter of getting used to it, though, so

you might wanna get some time in on VR now
so after the machines take over the Matrix

doesn&#39;t generate more stomach chutney than
power.

And of the commercial headsets on the market,
I do prefer the Playstation VR, it&#39;s more

comfortable to wear with glasses and easier
to set up, I only need to balance one motion

capturing device on the piles of empty cider
bottles that surround my comfy chair.

A new game came out for it this week called
The Inpatient, which in contrast to the last

VR game we did, Wilson&#39;s Heart, which was
about a dude in a haunted asylum where monster

shit&#39;s going down, is a game about a dude
in a haunted asylum where monster shit&#39;s going
down.
Well, let&#39;s be fair.

For it&#39;s faults, Wilson&#39;s Heart had puzzles,
and some combat, and in brief, stuff happening,
whereas in The Inpatient, erm... hm.

Well, it&#39;s got some very lovely corridors
you&#39;ll have plenty of chances to get acquainted
with.

The Inpatient is a prequel of sorts to Until
Dawn, that branching path slasher movie game

from a while back, and so it takes a few moments
to remind us at length that our choices will

have consequences, for example, if we choose
to get bored and stop playing, that will have

the consequence of a slightly more enriching
afternoon.

We&#39;re a patient in an asylum who&#39;s locked
in their cell when the monsters throw a housewarming

party and ends up trapped in there for weeks
with nothing to snack on but mildew and an
increasingly unhinged roommate.

We have a couple of nightmares during this
sequence that call upon us to walk down a

hallway while occasionally a scary thing suddenly
appears and makes a noise like it&#39;s screaming

while hitting the inside of a trash can with
a cricket bat.

I mean, come on, guys, surely the budget could
stretch far enough that you didn&#39;t have to

steal jumpscares from Newgrounds escape the
room horror games.

But then of course we get to the part of the
game after we get out of the cell, which consists

largely of following characters very slowly
down dark corridors, and then I was like &quot;Fucking

hell, all is forgiven, jumpscares, come back
and liven this the fuck up.&quot;

I&#39;m just gonna spoil a lot of the Inpatient
because trust me, missing out on this one

is not going to haunt you to your dying days
- the thrust of this and Until Dawn&#39;s premise

is that if you eat human flesh you turn into
a Wendigo, right?

And the main diversion of the plot is whether
you turn into a Wendigo or your roommate does.

Now, if the former, our roommate is absent,
presumably because we scoffed down their entire

body with french fries and ranch, but I don&#39;t
get why the roommate becomes a wendigo in

the other scenario because we&#39;re self-evidently
not eaten.

And I don&#39;t remember looking down at any point
and seeing that one of my legs was chewed
off.

Just a little plot hole, but there&#39;s so little
plot one hole turns it into a fucking engagement
ring.

It all culminates in the fantastic ending
where we get to the cable car to escape the

mountain asylum and one character turns to
whoever&#39;s turning into a wendigo and goes
&quot;Hey, you&#39;re turning into a wendigo.&quot;

&quot;Yes, I figured as much, bit of a pisser,
isn&#39;t it?&quot;

&quot;Well how about all of us who are not wendigos
sit in the cable car and you can stay here
and start it for us?&quot;
&quot;Alright, fair enough.&quot;
That was the fucking final boss, was it?

The explosive climax that I walked slowly
down a whole five or six corridors for?
Eat shit, the Inpatient.

VR games really need to grow out of making
open quotes &#39;experiences&#39; rather than games.

They always make me feel the way I feel after
riding one of those simulator rides at a theme

park - I can&#39;t believe I spent my allowance
on that.

So, with that in mind, let&#39;s talk about another
VR game I played this week which, controversially,

was a game, and not just a walking simulator
with no concept of personal space - Doom VFR,

which knowing Doom probably stands for Virtual
Fucking Reality.

I know they were going for badass, but when
you say it out loud it kinda sounds like you&#39;re
sick of the whole concept.
Virtual Fucking Reality!

Anyway, Doom VFR presents itself as a side
story to the recent Deum, where we play a

random dude who was in the Mars facility when
the demons took over, but seemed to have already

been partly zombified because he has a weird
habit of holding his hands out in front of

him the whole time like a sleepwalker with
a sensitive priapism.

Fortunately the demons swiftly bite it off
along with a large percentage of his body,

but our hero was smart enough to back up his
personality on the solid state drive that
morning so he ends up in a robot body somehow.

So because VR tends to favour shorter games
so you don&#39;t play it for eight hours and get

miniature TVs permanently fused to your eyeballs,
what follows is a sort of Cliff&#39;s Notes version

of Doom 2016 where we teleport around to some
choice locations from the game, pursue some

nondescript button pressing objective and
more importantly rip off enough demon todgers
to at least partially satisfy your mum.
So this is Deum designed for VR.

It&#39;s presumably possible to play original
Deum with VR but you&#39;d either need a concrete
inner ear or a tarpaulin to sit on.

In VFR, instead of the usual FPS free movement
we get around by teleporting and quick dashing
from spot to spot.

And bite my nipples off and call me Billy
Notits if it doesn&#39;t bloody work pretty well.

In fact I think this is the first VR game
I&#39;ve played that&#39;s pulled off the high octane

shooty action and didn&#39;t even make me feel
sick.

It made my head hurt, but you know, mum always
warned you that would happen if you sat too

close to the TV so what the fuck did you expect
would result of strapping the TV to your fucking
face.

My expectations were low &#39;cos from every description
I read it sounded like they were just gonna

turn Deum into a pop-up shooting gallery,
like a ferocious wolf being forced to mate

with a ridiculously ambitious corgi but rest
assured absolutely none of Deum&#39;s trademark
frenetic challenge is lost.

Teleport across the room, shotgun two imps
in the face, let them all gather round for

a space marine nipple salad then teleport
back out and rocket the place where you just

were, ha ha, it&#39;s just good old plain unqualified
fun.

That said, the fun spikes highest when you
are engaged in pitched battle and warping

around a big open arena, but at other times
you have to move down narrow corridors and

in that case you feel a little bit silly teleporting
your way along six feet at a time like a little
hoppy murder bunny.
And turning around is a bit of an arse.

Freely rotating yourself is still bad for
motion sickness or perhaps I mean extremely

good for motion sickness so we&#39;re still having
to rotate in something like 30 degree increments,

which is all very well when your game consists
of walking very slowly down corridors fretting

over whether you should have had all that
human flesh for breakfast, not so much when

you&#39;ve just teleported away from a heated
debate with several cacodemons and would like

to turn back around and deliver a double-barrelled
counterargument.

Besides that, some of my criticisms of vanilla
Deum still apply, gets a bit too easy towards

the end when all the ridiculously powerful
guns have been introduced and are now just

lying around everywhere like there was an
earthquake in an American high school locker
room, but it doesn&#39;t really hurt the game.
So that&#39;s it.

Doom VFR possibly a leap forward for VR action
games, The Inpatient possibly a leap forward
into a ditch full of very uninteresting rocks.
